a poor team, if well supported, will
oftentimes play much better than it is
ordinarily able to play.
Therefore we feel that the return of
the Freshman regulations next year,
which include the compulsory attendance of freshmen at all games, would
be a very wise move and that it would
be extremely beneficial to all concerned.
During the past year the frosh have
been very lax in their attendance of
the games and when they did come,
only a few sat in the cheering section
and lent their voices to the cheering.
With the return of freshman regulations, the teams would at least be assured of the support of the first year
men and their attendance would set
the example for others to come out.

Consent of Subject Necessary

Three stages, Lethargy, Catalepsy and Somnambulism are noticed in a hypnosis, and there are
various means of putting a subject
from one stage into the other, professors say. Usually the consent of
any normal individual, it was explained, must be gotten before he
may be hypnotized, for by his own
efforts, a fatigue of one of the
senses (usually conversion strabismus of the eye) is a necessary
prelude to the state.

Entries for the Adams declamation and the De Tocqueville lecture
contests at the Johns Hopkins must
be filed before midnight today with
Charles Ney, of the Rochester
Apartments, Linden avenue. Topics
in the respective literary meets must
be submitted together with entries.
Sophs Eligible In Adams Meet
All undergraduates are eligible
for the De Tocqueville contest;
sophomores, for the Adams competition. Speeches are to be limited
to six minutes.
American prose selections of the
twentieth century, with the exception of those dealing with political
problems, will be acceptable in the
declamation contest, tryouts for
which are to be held Thursday in
Levering Hall, Room B, 11:30
A. M.
Tryouts Saturday
For the De Tocqueville contest
contestants must deliver a lecture in
English on any phase of French
history of the present and nineteenth centuries. Tryouts are scheduled for Saturday, 1 P. M., Leverino- Hall, Room B.

Chemical Hygiene Professor Addresses Medical Society On Mineral's Effects
The part played in human growth
and health by minerals in food that
humans eat was discussed Monday
night before the semi-annual meeting of the Baltimore City Medical
Society by Dr. Elmer V. McCollum, professor of chemical hygiene
at the J. H. U. School of Hygiene
and Public Health.
An internationally known authority on nutrition, Dr. McCollum,
has for several years been experimenting to determine the physiological importance of certain
minerals found in the body and in
normal diet.

Preference is given in awarding
the Ella E. Slack Scholarship, to
graduate students in those subjects
of study in connection with which
there is no other endowed scholarship or fellowship. It was established by the late Mrs. Ella E.
Slack, who died November 4, 1923.
The endowment was $6,730.
Founded Three Scholarships
Mrs. Harriet Lane Johnston, of
Washington, formerly of this city,
in memory of her husband and two
sons, founded the three Johnston
scholarships in 1904. They are
awarded annually by the trustees
to men and women who have given
evidence of the power of independent research and who expect to
devote themselves to research in
their chosen subjects.
The stipend is $1,500 annually.
To Hold Cabaret
A cabaret party, which was an
outstanding success of 1930 June
Week, according to Yellott, will
be again held in Levering Hall.
Music will be furnished by T.
Worth Murphy's Belvedere Band.
Guy Lombardo and his Royal
Canadians will furnish the music
at the Senior Ball.
NOTICE
Coach Hambleton is extremely
anxious that all men having been
"working out" on the track attend
the practices this week. This applies particularly to the "Junior
Varsity" men, who are to engage
the team from "Poly" on Friday.
This Jay \Tee-Poly meet is a yearly
affair and proves to be very interesting aside from providing experience for the younger men.

a poor team, if well supported, will

Therefore we feel that the return of
the Freshman regulations next year,
which include the compulsory attendance of freshmen at all games, would
be a very wise move and that it would
be extremely beneficial to all concerned.
During the past year the frosh have
been very lax in their attendance of
the games and when they did come,
only a few sat in the cheering section
and lent their voices to the cheering.
With the return of freshman regulations, the teams would at least be assured of the support of the first year
men and their attendance would set
the example for others to come out.

colleges and many sections of the
country, the conference lasted all

held, and a total of eight speakers
presented their views to the group.

several other colleges and universities.

Easy competition of this sort may
give the Hopkins team a chance to
pile up points, but it does not offer

The attack is undoubtedly strong,
but the defense has had little opportunity to display its ability.
Fritz Stude, Jay goalie, has not had

only had to stop about a half a

in a beautiful style.
Instead of proving an advantage
to the team, these easy games are
really a hindrance. Stronger competition will prove the best test.

Consent of Subject Necessary

Three stages, Lethargy, Catalepsy and Somnambulism are noticed in a hypnosis, and there are
various means of putting a subject
from one stage into the other, professors say. Usually the consent of
any normal individual, it was explained, must be gotten before he
may be hypnotized, for by his own
efforts, a fatigue of one of the
senses (usually conversion strabismus of the eye) is a necessary
prelude to the state.
And now, if you spy a somewhat
serious-looking college man firmly
admonishing either his kid sister,
brother or girl friend that they are
a bear, llama, or Cleopatra respectively,—that, gentle reader is not a
case for Fipps Clinic . . . no . . .
merely a scientific demonstration of
hypnotism.

December, 1925, the Trustees received from Mrs. George B. Hunting $5,000 for the foundation of a

in the political science department
of the graduate school are eligible
for the scholarship which amounts

Togeler Bequeathed $5,000
Charles A. W. Vogeler, alumnus
of the Hopkins, who died March
21, 1919, bequeathed $5,000 to the
Trustees to be used as a fellowship
in Greek archaeology.
On the recommendation of the
zoology department, the Academic
Council awards the A. T. Bruce
Fellowship for research in biology
at a place approved by Dr. Ames.
The mother of Dr. Bruce, fellow
and instructor at the University,
founded the fellowship in 1887.
Used For Archaeology Students
A bequest of approximately $5,000 annually by Cornelia G. Harcum, student in the archaeological
department, has been used by the
trustees as a scholarship open to
women students in Classical archaeology.

Entries for the Adams declamation and the De Tocqueville lecture
contests at the Johns Hopkins must
be filed before midnight today with
Charles Ney, of the Rochester
Apartments, Linden avenue. Topics
in the respective literary meets must
be submitted together with entries.
Sophs Eligible In Adams Meet
All undergraduates are eligible
for the De Tocqueville contest;
sophomores, for the Adams competition. Speeches are to be limited
to six minutes.
American prose selections of the
twentieth century, with the exception of those dealing with political
problems, will be acceptable in the
declamation contest, tryouts for
which are to be held Thursday in
Levering Hall, Room B, 11:30
A. M.
Tryouts Saturday
For the De Tocqueville contest
contestants must deliver a lecture in
English on any phase of French
history of the present and nineteenth centuries. Tryouts are scheduled for Saturday, 1 P. M., Leverino- Hall, Room B.

Chemical Hygiene Professor Addresses Medical Society On Mineral's Effects
The part played in human growth
and health by minerals in food that
humans eat was discussed Monday
night before the semi-annual meeting of the Baltimore City Medical
Society by Dr. Elmer V. McCollum, professor of chemical hygiene
at the J. H. U. School of Hygiene
and Public Health.
An internationally known authority on nutrition, Dr. McCollum,
has for several years been experimenting to determine the physiological importance of certain
minerals found in the body and in
normal diet.

Preference is given in awarding
the Ella E. Slack Scholarship, to
graduate students in those subjects
of study in connection with which
there is no other endowed scholarship or fellowship. It was established by the late Mrs. Ella E.
Slack, who died November 4, 1923.
The endowment was $6,730.
Founded Three Scholarships
Mrs. Harriet Lane Johnston, of
Washington, formerly of this city,
in memory of her husband and two
sons, founded the three Johnston
scholarships in 1904. They are
awarded annually by the trustees
to men and women who have given
evidence of the power of independent research and who expect to
devote themselves to research in
their chosen subjects.
The stipend is $1,500 annually.
To Hold Cabaret
A cabaret party, which was an
outstanding success of 1930 June
Week, according to Yellott, will
be again held in Levering Hall.
Music will be furnished by T.
Worth Murphy's Belvedere Band.
Guy Lombardo and his Royal
Canadians will furnish the music
at the Senior Ball.
NOTICE
Coach Hambleton is extremely
anxious that all men having been
"working out" on the track attend
the practices this week. This applies particularly to the "Junior
Varsity" men, who are to engage
the team from "Poly" on Friday.
This Jay \Tee-Poly meet is a yearly
affair and proves to be very interesting aside from providing experience for the younger men.
